Riff Racer, what a game. To be honest, I did not expect it to be so good. This is one of those games that you put your music into and they generate a racing track, which fits the music. Even though it's in Early Access, it does its job better than other game of the same genre.Below the final verdict is the complete list of music that I've played for this review.Pros: Terrific surroundings (skyscrapers, spotlights, etc.) It does a really good job at converting the music into the track you are driving on. The drops are amazing, boost pickups are synchronised with the beats and even landings fit the music! Even though it's a racing game, I did not expect to see drifting in this game. It's awesome! There are jumps, flips, pickups, boosts and other stuff. There is a wide choice of vehicles that can be used in-game. Also, you can buy skins for them using "chips" you earn while playing. One of the main benefits (in my opinion): the graphic details are astonishing even on older computers. The game uses a low amount of system resources. There are no lags or disruptions in the music you're playing. Even if you crash, the music keeps going. This is not the case in Audiosurf, though. Even when you crash, use boost or in any way change your speed, the landscape is always synchronised with the current music. I don't know how they did it, but it's amazing. There are achievements and leaderboards.Cons: There is no music that comes with the game itself. If you want to play, you need your own music library first. | This feature has been added.  No autoplay/playlist option. When you finish a song, you have to pick the next one by hand. | This feature has been added. Achievement Unstoppable is not working properly. The player is supposed to unlock it when he completes a level without hitting any barricades. However, it can also be unlocked by restarting the level as soon as music starts to play. No advanced graphic options. I know I have mentioned in the upsides that you don't actually need to lower the quality as it runs just fine on most of the computers. It is still a good idea to include more options. Some barricades are extremely hard to see and therefore avoid, especially after jumps. If the music file is more silent than usual, the game sounds might be louder than the music itself. I only had this problem with The Writer, but there should be some kind of a detection system that would lower the game sounds, if necessary.The final verdict:There are quite a few downsides, but they don't really matter that much. I really enjoyed my time in this game so far as it is an awesome experience for both your ears and eyes. 												So, I fire up Riff Racer: Race Your Music!. What do I want to listen to? Riff Racer allows me to select anything from my MP3 files, so I pull up my MP3 list of songs and decide on Gojira’s latest album (Magma). I decide the title track will fit my mood perfectly. Ahead of me lies a neon track, spanning off into the horizon and far beyond what the naked eye can see. The music queues up, the song begins and my car starts accelerating. I deftly maneuver around an obstacle, and then, heart racing, I take a slide around a bend in the track, narrowing missing the rail as I get my car under control, hit a boost point, and go flying off of a jump, only to barely land on the next section of track. Before me waits an amusement park loop which I take at super boosted speeds. The music blaring, the track continues to form before me, the beat and dynamics of the song dictating where the game will take me next. A few minutes later, I cross the blue finish line, having finished with 100% synchronicity, good for quite a few points. I now hold first place on a track of my own creation.StoryThis isnt applicable. The story is really the track and how it responds to your musical selection, and how you respond to the track in turn.GraphicsThe graphics are quite cool looking. As mentioned in my intro, the tracks in Riff Racer are neon constructed out of and into nothingness. The horizon is ever your goal, and Riff Racer sends you there full throttle in a glowing world of bass, beats, and guitar (or whatever makes up the whole of the songs you select). To an extent, Riff Racer’s graphics are minimal, and yet you cant help but draw similarities to games like Tron, albeit beefed up and modernized.Overall, the graphics in Riff Racer aren’t mind blowing, but they do look really cool. I would give them an 8 out of 10GameplayThis is where Riff Racer truly shines. As a game that creates your experience around the music you select, Riff Racer does an exceptional job of being a dynamic, time and points based solo racing game. You can never see very far ahead, and so you will be constantly reacting to the world as Riff Racer shifts and creates the track based on the dynamic of the music.There are loops, jumps, obstacles, boosts, and plenty of twists and turns that offer opportunities to not only race full throttle, but also to get your drift on. My own best drift was right at 16 beats. Jumps are also timed, and you score more points based on how many beats your jump is good for. Depending on the angle of release on your jumps, you might also spin in the air, which counts as a trick that also garners you more points. Additionally, any special moves help to fill up your boost meter.Your boost meter is an essential part of Riff Racer. Basically, boosting allows you to stay ahead of the beats, which is your ultimate goal. You want to at the very least try to stay with the first beat at all times, but getting ahead of it will net you even more points. In addition to tricks, there are also coins and boxes all along the track that will also help fill your boost meter. Finally, there are also boosts along the track as well. The more you stay in boost mode, the more points you will earn. Points will allow you to rise in level, which will earn you bonus coins.Speaking of coins, you will earn those in each track by running over actual coins and boxes, by creating a track yourself (which, in Riff Racer, means you were the first to drive a track with any given song), by beating existing top 5 scores, and so on. You can use the coins to buy different cars and different skins for said cars. There is a notable difference in the various cars. The skins are just cosmetic.The controls are tight and fully responsive. Any time you are out of control in Riff Racer, it is because you over compensated, generally as a reaction to having to make some split second decisions. You can of course play the same track over and over, so once a track for a song has been created, it will always remain the same, and you can memorize the twists and turns in hopes of getting better scores.Riff Racer does what it needs to do perfectly. I give gameplay a 10 out of 10.SoundThe sound is always 100% in your hands in Riff Racer, as it is always determined by your own musical preference. The music playing is always your own choice, and that is 100% the in game sound.So, this is an easy 10 out of 10 as well. It is exactly what you make of it. You are 100% in control of what you hear.VerdictAs a music powered game, Riff Racer shines in every way. Played for hours at a time or a few songs at a time, Riff Racer keeps on giving and giving. You wont ever really tire of the experience Riff Racer provides, and Riff Racer is a game you will continue playing 5 or even 10 years from now. This is what I would consider a must own for any music and/or driving fans out there. Good times will be had aplenty.

												I was hesitating on this one since a lot of rhythm type games that generate tracks from user audio files feel kinda bland or else they have the problem of only being fun if you are using EDM tracks with heavy, distinctive beats. I was watching some trailers as well and was hesitating because I couldn't really discern what the game was doing with the tracks that would make them truly feel like you were playing the song.After spending just a short amount of time with it, it's winning me over very fast. It's called Riff Racer, which suggests guitar riffs, which suggests it should be fun with rock music, whereas a lot of music/rhythm games that procedurally generate tracks are not super good with rock tracks. I was super impressed to discover that playing rock tracks in this game feels very satisfying and the game can specifically detect if you are a playing a rock/metal track.As I was playing these rock songs, which don't have the heavy, distinctive beats that EDM tracks have, I kinda started to warm up to the things the game was doing to make you feel like you were playing the song. It was less about individual beats and more about the energy of the song. Placing a speed boost right when the chorus takes off. Dropping a huge ramp right when the song tears into a guitar solo. Shifting the lighting and colors to fiery hot as the song picks up speed and volume. Where Riff Racer lacks at emphasizing the individual beats of a song, it seems to excel at getting the visceral energy of a song just right. Of course I'd advise you to mostly pick out a songs that suit a game about hitting ramps in a fast car.The game has great controller support and the controls are fantastic. The driving feels almost as good as games like Mario Kart or Sonic All-Star Racing Transformed. The drifting takes a bit of getting used to, but its starts to make more sense the more you practice it.It's an arcade racer, so it's all about racking up points. Unlike other rhythm games, which focus on hitting the good objects and dodging the bad objects, Riff Racer does something slightly different. Hitting the good objects instead builds up a boost meter that you can use to trigger a manual boost (in addition to free boosts lying on the track). In order to get the most points, you need to go as fast as possible for as long as possible, hit collectibles, hit ramps (especially at an angle so that you can spiral jump for extra points), and execute long drifts around sharp corners. The faster and fancier you drive without falling off the track, flipping the car, or crashing into things, the more points you'll rack up. It's not just about hitting those beats (although it's that too); it's also about kicking butts.And of course there are global leaderboards, friend leaderboards, personal best, etc. The game comes with a bunch of songs bundled in, and you can use your own. You also gain points for racing tracks, and those points let you unlock new cars and paint jobs. The new cars and paint jobs are merely cosmetic, but it gives you something to work toward if you need that kind of motivation.The only downside to the game is that once you put 4 or 5 hours into it, race all of your favorite rock tracks, then you've pretty much seen the whole tour. You can still go back and score attack, but you're basically racing time trial on tracks that---while very fun---are largely similar, so it starts to get a little samey after a while.Rating the game on the scale below, I give it a hearty 6:7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.6) A good game that is worth the full price.5) A pretty good game worth checking out--especially if discounted.4) A fairly good game, but I'd recommend buying it discounted.3) Not great, but a few redeeming qualities. Only buy if heavily discounted.2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.1) Avoid at all costs.

I'm assuming this is how they keep track of the leaderboard scores. If you have music without a tag you can always get something like MP3Info, a great utility that adds ID3 tags and customizing to files. All in all I would say this game has great potential and recommend it to anyone who loves driving games and music.

Riff RacerDeveloper: FOAM EntertainmentPublisher: FOAM EntertainmentIntroduction==========It's not often that I take interest in a game that even remotely resembles a racing game. However, Riff Racer is one of the extremely rare exceptions. Using your own music (or the included bundle of 25 songs) to generate racetracks, Riff Racer has you racing the music itself to earn points and coins. Your experience depends entirely on YOU and what music you load up into the game.Gameplay==========Riff Racer creates racetracks based on the songs in your music library. When you boot up the game you can direct the game to any folder on your PC with music in it and have it generate a special track specific to that song. All the different verses, choruses, drops, and more are styled to the music you load and become checkpoints.  Even the car you drive shares some characteristics of the music. The point of the game is to stay in time with the music and score as many points as you can. Staying in sync offers a 4x modifier, while being ahead offers a 10x modifier. If you fall behind, either by not using boosts or hitting obstacles, your modifier drops until you can catch back up with the music. Each track you load has a 1 to 5 star rating. The more stars, the more obstacles you'll face on the track. As you race on each track, you'll run into barriers, jumps, and pits that may impede you. There's also these small white cubes that fill up your boost meter. Collect 10 of these to get a boost at the press of a button. There's also coins to collect that are used to buy different cars and paint jobs for them. The points you earn go towards increasing your Driver Level. All this does, as far as I know, is show how much you've played the game. I've not seen or found any benefit to having a higher Driver Level.Graphics==========This game is pretty psychadelic. Sounds and colors everywhere, just blaring and blinking in time with the music. Mostly various shades of red and yellow, but it honestly looks pretty awesome. The backgrounds look pretty cool, as well as the buildings and structures you'll ride past. A small detail I noticed that's probably really obvious is that your modifier and your boost meter are shown on the back of your car. As your modifier goes up, your car will crackle with energy.Sound and Music==========The music depends on you. Play using your favorite songs for maximum enjoyment! I like video game music, so the vast majority of the songs I played are from some of my favorite video games. The gameplay demo videos below feature a Mega Man X remix and a track from Ys VI.Performance==========Riff Racer ran nigh perfectly on my custom rig. No FPS drops, played at 60+ FPS at nearly all times (dropping ever so slightly during Super Sync and Boosting), and no stuttering. I played mostly with my controller, but it's easy enough to play with a keyboard if you don't have a controller. You just have to steer and hit the boost key...simple enough right?Final Thoughts==========This is an awesome racer, even moreso if you play with your favorite tracks! Pretty much anyone can enjoy Riff Racer. You can tailor the game to your liking with different songs and car customization. If you get the chance to buy this game, I urge you to pick it up...especially if it's on sale.Gameplay Demo==========

												This is a fun, inventive, and interesting way to enjoy your music. If you like music and you like gaming, buy this.However, I want to address some concerns that negative reviews bring up:1) To those who say the game is too easy, I must insist you post higher scores than me on the same songs. This is why a leaderboard system exists. I will happily send you an mp3 gift of any song of your choosing, and then we can decide together if the game is too easy for you.2) I disagree that the specific song doesn't affect the track or gameplay significantly. The music isn't merely "background." In my experience, a song's crescendos, breakdowns, drops, and even minor variations result in loops, jumps, curves, and other set pieces. I can't imagine how one could miss this connection, but everyone is entitled their experience. Maybe my music is just more fun to drive.3) It's true that there isn't a ton of "unlockable" content. How could there be? This game is limited only by your music library. Yes, you can unlock new cars that only differ in appearance, and that's all there is to it. Would you really want the devs to artificially limit the manuverability of your car at the outset just to give you a false sense of progression?One of the most popular rhythm games of all time, Dance Dance Revolution, contained unlocks. What did they give you? New songs, new characters. This game gives you all of the songs in the world as tracks, but you can purchase a handful of cosmetic upgrades with the coins you collect from racing. It's not intended to be a deep experience nor should it be.4) If you don't have a gamepad, don't buy a racing game  on PC and expect keyboard buttons to have the same degree of control as an analog stick. 								The concept of this game is pretty fun. It's rare to see a music game where you're quite literally competing against the music. Posted: August 10, 2016
												Riff Racer, previously called Drive Any Track, is basically Audiosurf without the match-3 puzzles. You load up a song from your hard drive, and the game generates a unique track for you to drive through, letting you compete for high scores with anyone else who's played the same track. The controls and presentation are simply sublime. Racing feels like F-Zero with its high speeds and crazy jumps; you really have to pay attention to the shape of the upcoming track if you don't want to wipe out. The smooth animation and futuristic visual style is wickedly awesome as well.Your score is mostly based on the stunts you perform; you get points for the length of each jump, double points for performing a mid-air roll, points for drifting around corners, and points for collecting crates. You lose points for hitting barriers, falling off the track, or flipping the car over. Additionally, if you start falling behind the song, your multiplier will diminish, and if you boost ahead of the song, you’ll get awarded with a whopping 10x multiplier. You can’t stay ahead of the song forever, so you’ll have to use your boosts strategically, not unlike star power in Guitar Hero games. Also interesting is that drifting won’t award points unless you’re actually driving around a corner – no fish-tailing exploits allowed.Although there's only a half-dozen game elements such as jump pads, boost pads, and collectables, the game succeeds in making every track feel like a unique experience – if you’re competing for a high score, you'll find that each track has its own distinct personality traits that you'll have to learn intimately. The track generator also takes some reasonable precautions to make sure you can see obstacles coming -- for instance, it zooms out the camera on loop-de-loops if there are barriers on the track, and it doesn't place barriers right after the peak of a hill. It demonstrates some impressive attention to detail, and makes casual play surprisingly relaxing and cathartic. There are exceptions, of course; you're bound to run into some surprising jumps and tricky turns, but half the fun of these kinds of games is memorizing your favorite tracks so that you can outscore the competition with the help of foresight. There's no difficulty toggle. However, some songs will be harder than others, denoted with a difficulty rating from one to five stars. If you want to find the most difficult songs, you'll have to hunt for them.The coolest feature of the game is being able to race against ghosts of other players. Oddly, the game doesn’t actually involve much “racing”; the only thing that matters is score, not your position on the track. Also weird is how you can’t race against any ghost you want, but only a predetermined list of 1-4 people who have beaten your high score (unless you hold the world record on a game, in which case you’ll be able to race against your own ghost and the ghost of the 2nd place holder).I give Riff Racer 8.8 / 10. This tops Beat Hazard as my favorite "media player" game to date. My only gripes have to do with some elements of the GUI; I wish the song selector were better, I wish you’d have more options of ghosts to race against. I wish you could see your boost meter and the ghost's score on the HUD without having to look at the cars themselves. It also wouldn’t hurt to see a few more game elements added to races. But overall, it fantastically does what these types of games are supposed to do: make you feel like you’re really getting into your favorite music. The final achievement is quite grindy, but I actually don’t mind, since I can see myself playing this game for a very long time. Well done. I'm not a big fan of Early Access myself, but you can mark this down as an Early Access success story.

Early Access Review
								As a Fan of Beat Hazard (Another Music Based Game) I saw this game and had to give it a try, I have almost 3 hours of gameplay into DAT, theses are my thoughts...   Gameplay  The Gameplay consists of you racing on custom tracks, hitting jumps, drifting around corners and avoiding barriers that slow you down while you try to stay in sync with your song, fall behind can result in you getting out of sync and losing the chance of getting a 100% synchronization on the song you are playing. There are currently 3 things I noticed you collect as you race, that is a 10 tokens (the currency), boxes that fill your boost and give you additional points to your total point score and a separate boosters icon that gives you a boost as soon as you touch it, keep in mind that this booster icon doesn't take away the progress of you filling your boost from you collecting the boxes, it is its own separate boost. This makes me think of the midnight club la's slipstreaming, you can build up the slipstreaming and use it, that way you don't use a nitrous bar, but you still get a boost. The Performance Optimization  is solid, constant 60 fps through gameplay with i5 3570k and gtx 760, The Recommended Requirements are pretty low, and I am impressed by that. A Intel Core 2 Duo and a Geforce 8000 series are pretty old components to run a game like this. But this makes this game playable for more people, so that is a good thing.  Song difficulty Rating System  needs some work I think, for example I played a song by the uk power metal/speed metal band "Dragonforce" and these guys make a bunch of songs with intense guitars solos, and their tempo of their songs are just fast and the game only rated this Dragonforce Song a 1 star out of 5 star and then I played the Nickelback song "When We Stand Together" and apparently that song is rated 5/5, so I don't know how it's rating system works, it must work in a way that I don't understand or it's just not very accurate in this Alpha build of DAT . There are other songs that I played that I felt didn't match what I would rate the song in difficulty based on the tempo of the song, etc. but as example of a song that I thought it did well in rating is "Beneath The Tides" by Ravenface, this song has a pretty fast tempo to it also, and the game rated it a 4/5 and I thought that was fitting and the Track Generation for this song was solid, lots of jumps, dips, and long corners to drift around (I got a 38 beat drift on the one part of the track and I freaked out haha) I found it a very fun song to race on, While on the Subject of Track Generation, let's talk about that next.  Track Generation  it's kind of decent for it being in alpha currently, it can do what I think is a good job generating to match a certain part of a song, but then in some songs, I will be questioning "why did you generate (this part) of the track?" but it is in alpha, so I am not expecting this to be perfect, but I feel it still does good for the most part, but might be because I just like hitting the jumps and drifting and the driving style of this game in general... Speaking of jumps and drifting and just the overall handling of the cars... let's talk about handling.  Handling of Cars  The handling of the cars are excellent in my opinion, the drifting is nice and you can really control your drifting which I really like. The Inferno Car is currently my favorite Car.     Ranking System   there is a ranking system in this game, it's seems to be pretty basic from what I noticed so far, you just get points from doing songs, and thus your points add up to level you up , the current reward that I noticed so far is some of the tokens in the game to buy paint jobs for your cars, which there are 2 paint jobs for each of the 7 cars of 15 or so cars total that I have unlocked so far.To Summarize+Fun+ Solid Gameplay=Decent Track Generation+Excellent FPS (solid 60 fps) / Low System Requirements- Song Difficulty Rating system needs a little work for some songs/genres+ Excellent Car Handling/Drifting= Ranking System is Basic, but Solid for this gameOverall 8.5/10

												Must be the music I like, since even the slow music sometimes throws me off the track with ramp after ramp after ramp.  That being said ...This is a great game.  It's quite enjoyable to run the tracks trying to get a decent score while listening to music you enjoy.Most of my music is two stars, with a few three stars, and I've had a few pop up as four stars.  I've yet to see a five star song from my music ...  Maybe I should be careful what I ask for, as four star songs are pretty wild!The way you get points is by doing stunts.  You keep ahead of the first bar for maximum points.  Just driving doesn't get you anything, although you can use periods where you need to just drive to collect coins (for buying different cars and skins) and boost pack thingies (that you can use to activate your own boost whenever you want ... provided you've collected enough of them).You always take about the same amount of time to make it through the track, so to get points you do stunts.  You run over ramps, getting as much air time as possible.  To get more points, you hit the ramps so the car spins ... but this comes with a number of issues that really justifies the extra score.  For instance, if you hit the ramp wrong, it's possible to land on your roof, or be flung from the map altogether!  So be very very very careful jumping, especially if you plan on doing the high scoring spins!You also get points by drifting.  I suppose this can be abused, but whenever I've used drifting unnecessarily, I've always bounced off the walls.  Great way to fall behind, thus losing points!When you use the boost, it helps you get caught up, or you can use it just before a series of jumps to get ahead of the bar, increasing your point yield.  I'm the sort who tries to get more bang for my buck, so I always try to optimize when I use it.  But I rarely play the same track twice in a row, so it's always something of a gamble for me.If you play the same track over a few times to get the highest score you can, you won't have to wait for it to rebuild the track.  But if you go to another track, then come back to the first one, you'll have to wait for it to be rebuilt.  There's a "tip" that says that "you only have to wait the first time you play the track," but this is not entirely true.  It is only true if you play the track repeatedly, a few times in a row.Also, there are barriers on the road.  If bouncing off the walls, landing upside down after a trick jump, or flying clean off the road, aren't enough reasons to set you back, they stuck barriers on the road that will slow you down quite a bit.  Since you need to keep ahead of the first line to optimize your scoring, this can be quite a problem!You also lose points for every barrier you hit, so it's a good idea to avoid them for more than one reason.It can play m4a files, but not aac files.  Not a terribly large issue, just something to be aware of.  I do not know what other files it can play, as my library seems to be a mix of m4a and aac files.On difficulty:1 star - Very casual.  I think I've seen only one or two of these songs.  Maybe the Beehtoven one I played was one?  I don't recall.2 star - Casual.  This is where most of my music lands.  It actually has quite a diverse range of difficulty in this range.3 star - Normal.  You really have to start using all the tools it gives you to keep up here.  It can sometimes be pretty wild.4 star - Hard.  It's beginning to get wild here.  I've had about half a dozen of my tracks come up like this.  It leaves me crying with laughter at every surprise twist and turn it gives me, and it's hard to make normal jumps ... let alone the high point yield twisters, here!5 star - Insanity?  I've yet to see a song this hard, but I'm pretty sure most people would be falling off the track quite a bit here.  The maps may even be nearly unplayable!I generally listen to Indie music.  I look at the top tracks, and I don't see anything I actually have in my library on them, so I guess I can not race against the "most popular" track leaders.  In point of fact, it's pretty rare for me to play a track anyone else has played, so maybe I have it a bit easier than most people who play the game getting coins.

								Drive Any Track (DAT) is a fabulous game but only if you have lots of different types of music on your computer. So if you have things that you got legally (your progress is not recognized if you have an illegal copy) then this game will be very fun. Although, there are 10ish pre-installed tracks.The game finds the tempo of your music from an online service and creates a track with varying difficulty. Tempos from 100 bpm to 200 bpm are the standard. if its less than 100 then it would be counted as 0 being 100. So if you have  a song with a bpm of 50 then it'll be seen as 150 bpm. It is the same with 200+. If your music is 275 then it'll be seen as 175.Every track has its own leaderboard you can use to compete with yourself or with other people who have the same copy of the song you have. Audiosurf and its sequel have been long-time favorites for me. However, there was always something missing. There isn't a large amount of control you can give as you glide across a track to your favorite music.That's where Drive Any Track comes in. It improves upon that concept by giving you much more control over what you do on that track. You see that sharp turn over there? Yeeeeaaaaah... you can friggin' drift around that like a pro racer. What about that jump? Evil Knievel that as you sing along to the song. You have more control over how you literally drive the song.GameplayThe gameplay is a mixture of avoiding obstacles, collecting boxes for points/boost, collecting tokens for in-game customization, jumping off ramps (and landing them) all while staying in sync with the song you are playing. If you hit a barricade? You're going to lose some speed and possibly lose sync. Fail a jump? You might as well restart if you want that 100% bonus.As you finish songs to completion, you are given a place on the leaderboard for that song. If you were the first one to play that song, you are credited with being the track creator. Additionally, you are given XP for completing the song, which levels you up (which unlocks cars). The tokens you gathered throughout the songs can be used to buy paint-jobs for the cars you own.The game is essentially simple, which is to be expected of Early Access. Hopefully the developer adds some more game modes and spices up track generation.  Graphics/Sounds/Controls The game has simple graphics that allow the game to be played on a majority of low-end computers. The game is more focused on using simple, abstract and vibrant colors and lights to give the game more of an arcade-y feel that allows the game to portray different genres. I have not run into any performance issues as of yet.Sounds are entirely based on the quality of the audio file you are using. I recommend using the highest quality file to ensure the best listening pleasure.I have not used anything other than a keyboard for this game, so my experience in controllers or gamepads is non-existent. I can say that the games controls are simple and easy to learn. Playing on the keyboard is very useable as well. No need for controllers. Replayability The game's replayability is entirely dependant on the size of your music library. However, there are some problems where some songs will be given the wrong difficulty. Also, while every song has a unique track, it may get monotonous. The lack of different modes leave things to be desired. Overall The game is really good, it has massive potential. 								So, after a few tracks, heres a little First Look review of DATOn first glance you might say that this game seems a lot like audiosurf, just with an actual car instead of a polygonal glider.And Mono Mode only.Well, let me tell you - its not. While audiosurf is pretty much always straight ahead on 3 lanes, this right here is an actual racing game.Now, steering-wise the game is as simple as it gets. Left and right steer, Brake and gas arent needed, that does the game for you, CTRL is a handbrake for drifting and Space activates a Boost. Thats it.Your goal is to run a racetrack made from one of your songs and rack up as high of a score as you can. To do that you have to "stay in Sync" as the game tells you.Before you runs a visible line, thats where the track is right now on the race track. YOu can stay in a measure of 4 bars behind it to be in Synch and get the optimal amount of points for your tricks. if you fall more than 4 bars behind, you lose a multiplicator until you are at least 7 bars behind, where the game will set you back on track (with a respawn phase where you dont get any points. same for when you fly off the track)If you manage to overtake the Synch line, you enter a Supersynched mode where you amass more points but your speed and boost is slightly dampened, so you cant stay up there forever.Now, to get said points you just have to drive (a few points each measure of 4 beats), Jump (either by ramps on the track or by gaps in the track itself) Roll (same as jump - slightly tilted ramps or after Corkscrew Boosts) and Drift (by Using CTRL). After finishing a track you get some Boni depending on how good your driving was.Now what do I think? As someone who is pretty much terrible at racing games, I must say it is fun, plays pretty simple and even on Songs rated 4 Stars (out of 5) I managed to stay "in Sync" 60% of the time. Control is responsive, riding your tracks and experiencing your music completely different (again) feels nice and the Ghosting Modes (Race the world leader, the best ranked friend or a recommended random driver for a track) are fun too. Also, the mechanic of "discovering" tracks, by being the first player worldwide who has ever played that song gives the game a nice way of saying "Good job that you listen to different music!" However, Songs have to be IDE3 taggedto be accepted as discovered.As much as I like the game, It does have some flaws - sometimes the levels are built pretty counterproductive - like you get a boost into a long jump onto a sharp turn or you corkscrew a good 20 meters left to the track, sometimes when you resync you getdropped into a hole or a wall and lose more time and progress and its not really appearent weather or not you are drifting or if a drift has ended or has been aborted somehow. But since this game is early Acces as of now, it has room upwards.Not that it isnt far up alreadyIf you like racing games and you love music, this right here is a good buy.EDIT: Oh yeah - another little beef I have with this game - it does not save after a track, so when the game unexpectedly crashed I found myself short of the spoils of the previous 6 or 7 races.

												JANUARY 2017 UPDATED OPINION... (original review below this one)After coming back to this game after my initial purchase, I can say -some- of what I wrote in my original review might have sounded harsh. Most of the negatives still stand, but I feel this game is more of a "hmm, it's ok" than a downright "no". I have to say that "listening to your favorite music while driving some random track" is probably how I feel about it. Having a score to beat for one of my favourite bands (SCANDAL) has finally allowed me to appreciate this game more - even if the other guy has totally obliterated any chance I have of getting the best score.I still feel this game would be better if music packs were available to purchase - there is a lot of indie stuff out there, and I'm sure paid DLC would go a good way to making this game "bigger". Again, what I originally said in my original review still stands for the most part.END OF NEW OPINION. OLD REVIEW BELOW.Tl;DR - Stay away if you're expecting either a good racing game or good music game - this is neither!Got sucked in to buying this game, expecting more of a rhythm based game, than a "randomly" generated track to play from the song I selected. Unfortunately, it's neither a good racing game, nor is it a good music game: you are literally just racing with music in the background, and for most of the songs you try, the track will be fairly unexciting.Pros:• Select any mp3 song from your computer to generate a track• Trippy race-tracks• The cars all handle differentlyCons:• Very small selection of songs to choose from in-game - no songs I've heard of. This begs the question - did I just pay for a song to race-track generator? If so, I am disappointed.• Lacks any sort of story, and no proper levelling system, so it doesn't keep you wanting to play more; the only reason to keep playing more is to unlock more cars and paintjobs.• You're playing a race-track which has no real "rhythm" aspect to the game - it's all about doing drifts, keeping speed up, and not hitting walls or obstacles. Take away the music, and you'll realise you're just playing a lack-lustre race - the music only dictates the generation and "speed" of the level, not anything else.• The average song you will throw at the game will usually generate a rather boring track, I've found some of the weirder songs to generate better tracks. For example, I tried "Cherry Bomb" from Silent Siren, which created a challenging track, but then used a song from F-777 - Chinese Dance Machine, which created a rather tame, boring track. There doesn't seem to be a clear method to how a good race track gets generated.• No real feeling of accomplishment, as it's not like you can directly challenge others to beat your score unless they also have the same song (requires friends who also have this game), and you can't challenge a persons song directly either, you have to link your song first, there is no way to search for songs already played by others.The main thing that has gotten me to keep playing is the experimenting of throwing different songs at this to see how complex I can make the race track, and because I'm a bit of an acheivement hunter, I'll be "grinding" to get those cars and acheivements as well.Verdict: A drag to play, grinding for acheivements, no sense of competition/accomplishment. Like I mentioned, it's basically a race track generator without the real fun of a good racing game. Basically boils down to a zen-game in a way because of it. Not recommended unless the devs pull finger and integrate some sort of challenges that people can strive for, to give them reason to keep playing.

								Bear in mind, the game was an early access game at the time of this review.While this game can be very fun, there are some flaws that can marr the experience for some.First off, the game looks good. There are a few issues with the car having tiny white spots dance all over it when choosing your car, and that the bloom effect can sometimes hide barricades.Gameplay is simple and fun. It doesn't take much to get used to the controls, though in my experience steering can become wonky when you have to abort a drift. A major issue, though, is that the track generator has a bad habit of placing barricades right at the start of the loops, and of placing box trails and boosters in front of other barricades. This created "Gotcha" traps that you almost can't avoid when racing a track for the first time. If you are going for a high score, then it does stand to reason that you just memorize the placement of things on the track. But I feel it is a bit unfair to hit a ramp, only to see all too late that there is a barricade right where I'm landing. Or to reach a loop and have about half a second to veer to the side to avoid a set of barricades. For scoring points, the game heavilly rewards drifting and staying in sync or super sync with the song. The jumps and boxes do add to the score, but most of the times I've beaten someone elses high score, it was because of me drifting more than they did. The physics work fine for the most part. I have been turned around after a roll jump a few times, but not often enough that it was irritating.For the music, the tracks bundled with the game are okay. There is an issue there, though, if you shoot for achievements, as not all of the genres are covered by the bundled tracks. The game relies on Last.fm to determine tracks. But the detection isn't perfect, and for songs that aren't mainstream, like anything from OCRemix or the Newgrounds Audio Portal, the detection is useless. Songs from those sources are usually are mis-labled. In what way, I don't know, as the game doesn't tell you what genre the song falls under, and there are only three color schemes thus far: green for hip hop and funk, blue for dance and classical, and red for rock and metal.I do have a complaint about a couple of secrets in the game, in that there are zero in-game hints on how to unlock those secrets. Unless you spoil yourself buy looking on forums and discussions, you would have to be lucky to stumble across them.One thing I would like to see is something to spend coins on after all vehicles and their paint jobs are bought. Because that all coins are used for.All in all, for just being a bit of a bare bones early access game, I feel it is worth it to buy this game. Unless the devs try to fix things that aren't broken, it can only get even better from here.4/8/2016 EDIT: The white spots are gone as of the latest update.

Here In My Car, I'm Outdritin' 'Em All!Riff Racer = Audiosurf + Forever Drive + UNEXPLAINABLE HOMICIDAL RAGEIf you've played both Audiosurf and Forever Drive, I've pretty much just explained the game to you and if you like those two things just shut up and spend your money.For those unititated, this game is about generating a sort of race track/obstacle course based on your music, and playing through it in order to acheive a high score.  The primary appeal is seeing what kind of ride experience you get based on the song you pick.  Sometimes a track will fit SO perfectly to a song that you'll swear it was handmade and not randomly generated.  Other times you'll have a hard time discerning how your race and the song match up at all, but still find it enjoyable.In the case of Riff Racer, it places emphasis on the racing action and feels very much like a simplistic stunt racing game with pleasant, neon visuals.  The hook here is the fact that when you select a song that no one else out there has yet played, you generate a unique track that is FOREVER YOURS.  So anyone else out there choosing that song will race the track that YOU generated.  It adds a bit of a layer of discovery to the game, as well as interesting emergent competition.See...  This is where I have you tell you I just spent over an hour on a track based on ONE song.  ONE SONG.  Replaying it over and over.  Why...?Well, here I was picking songs that I both liked and thought were just eclectic enough to not have been played.  ...BUT I KEPT RUNNING INTO THIS ONE JAGOFF THAT HAD ALREADY LAID CLAIM TO THEM.  ONE GUY WHO JUST HAPPENED TO LIKE A BUNCH OF DIFFERENT SONGS THAT I LIKE AND WAS TRYING TO STEAL THEM FROM ME HOW DARE YOU SIR?!!?!Naturally, there was only one thing to do...Crush this pretender, cast down his claim to those musical lands, and claim the No. 1 Headband.It seriously sparks some sort of weird obsessive competition when you run into these scenarios.  It's kinda like when two scenesters that each think they are (bandname)'s biggest fan clash, and then the fur really flies!It's strange because otherwise this is one of those games that is chill as it gets.  Cruise through your music (Or even your podcasts!) and enjoy the visuals and cool Tron-like vehicles OR experience keyboard-smashing rage as you get freaky possessive about your special snowflake music!Start your engines if you... Loved the Audiosurf games.  Pretty much a must have for your collections. Like games that are trippy like woah! Have a bizarre need to defend your favorite songs as if they were your waifu.Put it in park if you... Are more so into DDR-style games.  This game is about mastering the drift, not the beats. Need couch co-op and the other plethora of features found in Audiosurf.  This game is currently pretty slim in that regard. Don't really listen to music that much.  Sure this is a stunt racing game, but a lot of the fun is seeing what kind of race track your favorite songs might make.The Bottom LineRiff Racer does what it does very well and with an even coat of polish.  I've dumped about five hours into it mostly in one sitting without even realizing it.  Not many games can claim to have that hold on a person. The track visuals really need expanding, as even the different color schemes end up feeling alike to one another.  More game modes, local co-op, more items, powerups, and track terrain would cement this game as a classic.As it stands, it's definitely worth your money as is... I give Drive Any Track a 9/10.

Some of the ways they incorporate drops for example, in the form of a long jump, or utilizing loop de loops as a target point in the song are spot on. Other times, it leaves a lot to be desired. There were songs that I feel had a lot going on, such as several hardcore songs which featured lots of heavy bass, which were only rated a one star. Other pop songs were rated a five. Just found it weird in the rating system and how the algorithm takes certain songs is all.However, is this game addicting and fun? Hell yeah it is. I find this a lot more fun and engaging than Audiosurf and there is so much promise in this game, especially for an alpha build. I look forward to following the progress of this game.

												Riff Racer is all I could've wanted out of the play-your-own-track subset of the music game genre. Here are a couple of things that the game pulls off really well:You can get plenty of playtime out of it if you have a somewhat sizeable music library sitting in your hard drive. Even if I hadn't picked the game up when it wasn't on sale, I would say it is still very much worth it if you don't want to wait simply for the sheer amount of time you can just spend playing track after track. Useful for people like me who have a good thousand albums sitting around that I haven't gone through, it gives me a bit of motivation to do so, especially considering that the game incentivizes play with in-game currency that you attain from just playing your tracks, used to unlock new cars and paint jobs.The game isn't particularly mechanically dense, but this really works in the game's favor. It's all score based rather than having you drive a closed circuit racetrack. What this essentailly entails is auto-acceleration being on by default and a big focus on manipulating your boost and doing tricks all the while driving clean to attain the best score multipliers, rather than trying to go as fast as you can as per any orthodox racing game. After all, you finish your "track" as soon as the song ends. There aren't that many tricks, but there is a skill involved in it, gathering boost boxes scattered on the track, knowing when to drift, to roll your car instead of just jumping normally, for example.The logic for "track" creation is very slick. I've only had a few songs where a blockade obstacle was placed unfairly, like at the start of a loop where I couldn't see it, but for the most part, it's great and really does pick out set-piece moments in your songs. The difficulty also varies from song to song, though sometimes the hardest songs are the ones you wouldn't expect. I've had drone music play at the highest difficulty and some high-tempo noise rock play on the easiest.The game is simple in its appearance and polygonal car models, but the colorful neon-laden tracks are easy on the eyes and easy to just get lost into a trance to when I try to pull off drift after drift. It's a great visualizer, which is a good thing to have for a game like this. It's never boring to look at, especially since the colors of the tracks vary depending on what genre of music you're playing.Here are a couple of things that the game could improve on in the future (as it is getting updates here and there).The leaderboard and social aspects of the game are just serviceable. You have a player profile page, but there isn't much to see on it. You can see what car you use most, what track you play the most, and that's about it in terms of useful information. Trying to see what tracks a friend has played, for instance, will only yield their most-played track. Along with this, despite using Last.fm as a basis for determining track genres, as far as I know, you don't have the ability to scrobble your tracks. This one's just a minor nitpick of mine, but still, both of these potential features are things Audiosurf had in spades over Riff Racer, and I'd really like to see it worked on.The only game mode you have here is the score-based one. There's no other way to play it, but what the game has to offer is still a lot of fun.Japanese unicode doesn't work and it just comes out as a bunch of question marks :(((Though flawed in some respects (which are just nitpicks on my part), Riff Racer is still, all-in-all, a really solid game. If I could describe it, I'd call it chill. The sort of chill where you just invite someone over and watch shows or movies in the dark while sipping something. Riff Racer's real chill to hang with. It's definitely worth checking out if you're into this type of game.

Early Access Review
								If you like Audiosurf, you will love this game. It was a frustrating start but after I practiced with the controls a bit, I do a bit better now. There are some great things and some not so great things so I will try to list them all.Great things: -Plenty of cars and paints for the cars.-Visually stunning.-Simple yet challenging. -Track variation is pretty good, although I have found a few songs where most of the song is just drifting back and forth which is quite boring. For the most part though, the tracks are pretty good.-Shiny! Not so great things:-If you have a downloaded song through YouTube or some other source, there is no leader board for that song.-Sometimes downloaded songs will play as a different songs-Barricades are placed in bad spots from time to time. Sometimes they are impossible to avoid unless you have the track memorized.-Visuals can become distracting if your eyes are sensitive to bright colors, flashes, and other such effects.-Controls are wonky. They just do not feel consistent. Sometimes they respond slow. Sometimes they are too twitchy (Example: pulling out of a drift will slam you into a wall) -Crate and token hitboxes are not consistent either. Sometimes you can drive right next to them and pick them up, other times they won't get picked up.-Lack of control customization and not being able to use mouse/gamepad. You cannot change controls. The controls consist of <- -> [spacebar] and CTRL. There was little tutorial too. I was unsure that I could drift until about my 20th race and then i got a tip saying CTRL was to drift.Overall, considering this is Early access, It is in pretty good shape. There are a few minor things that need to be changed/tweaked/added. But overall, it was worth the money. I would suggest this game to any music lover.

												This is a score-based ghost racing game. You're not competing for the best time, but rather who can navigate the track in a manner that scores the most points (largely by drifting, collecting boosts, and hitting jumps right). The game has a meter that travels along the road and the car auto accelerates to keep up with it.The track generation feature works surprisingly well with most songs I've tried, and provides an added level of exhilaration to the climaxes of the music, even for more classical/orchestral songs. The game does not feature real-time multiplayer, but I don't see that as a downside, as it would be rather clunky without making a huge shift in game play. The biggest con to this game is the clunky slow menu and the fact that there's no way for strangers to race against the songs you upload unless they happen to have the same niche taste in music.

 TL;DR - If you like casual/arcade racing games and Audiosurf, this is a no-brainer! Riff Racer (formerly known as Drive Any Track in Early Access) is a rhythm/racer fusion that takes your mp3 collection and generates a Trackmania-style racetrack based on the audio file.  If you are the first to play your mp3 (note: you need to have id3 tags on your mp3s), the game will enshrine you as the creator of the track for all of eternity!  You can race by yourself, or race against a ghost of another player who has driven the same song.  The driving mechanics are just "ok" in my opinion, I've played much smoother racing games.  However, this game should not be confused with a technical racer, it is definitely more of an arcade racer with rhythm game features mixed in.  You can utilize a decent selection of cars, and unlock at least a couple of hidden cars as well.  They have added some more customization options since the Early Access phase, but it is still not quite as fleshed out as what you'd see in other racing games.The rhythm aspects of the game are subtle but definitely there.  It's not quite as beat/rhythm focused as Audiosurf in terms of track pickups and obstacles, but the lights and colors of the track flash along with the beats and on certain drifts you can tap along with the beat to get the best result.  Overall, I'd give this game an 8/10.  It really excels on what it sets out to accomplish as a game, despite seeming bare bones in certain aspects that you'd be used to seeing in another racing game.  The game is truly as deep as your mp3 collection, much like Audiosurf, but the racing is enjoyable enough and ghost racing against a friend gets really competitive and fun :)If you'd like some gameplay footage, here's me racing against my good friend UncleDorky's ghost!

												   I really liked this game, it's fun and simple, there are no if's or but's about it. The controls are very simple, basic driving movement keys [Though default bound to arrows and not wsad] with the drift function being controlled from spacebar (Saints Row 3 anyone?) and a boost button for when you fill your boost meter, which is cleverly displayed on the car and not a HUD.   The cars themselves are many once you can afford them [W/ In-game coins found within songs] and the designs are radical but remnescent, fitting into the game world perfectly while maintaining styles that many of us should be able to recognize features of.  The tracks [Road/Highway] are very colorful, as anyone here who has played audiosurf will easily relate to, fitting the music in a good way, with little dancing pixels colorized and moving to the beat of the music. There are stright-ways, loops, jumps, and drift streches, all of which are pretty fun to drive on, all except the drift areas containing barricades you want to advoid. My biggest issue was jumping off the side of the track and hitting barracades while going for coins, but it was all fun, the gameplay isn't overly challenging and the cars are manuverable in air, making mistakes like that semi recoverable. This is  -not- Dark Souls DJ'ing on wheels, this is a fun game ment for everyone.  Coins end up being used for buying new cars and customization options for the cars you do own. You start off with one car that has one unlocked customization, a sporty design in a pretty blue. The songs seem to vary in coins amoung them, I had one song go as low as 90 coins and another up to 250. This does help keep the game a little more appealing since you end up setting goals for getting the cars and paints, though I am only left to wonder that if 250 coins per song is good, then cars and paints costing 20k+ would take quike awhile to get. You do level up as you gain experience points from each song and I can only assume higher levels gives higher coin multiplyers, but that is just my assumption and in no way should I ever be quoted on it.   I don't have any gripes, as much as I tried to find one. While I was playing with the truck I did see my truck reflecting off the truck, which... makes no sence... and I once had a spotlight-beam cross the road for a second, but the map is littered with spotlights, as well as many other eye glittering detail. I have not been able to have this issue reoccure since, even on the same song it appeared on. The only thing that I would like to see is a super drift mode, or maybe a split game from this using the same physics, as the drift portions are very fun and arcade-like. I suppose one can compain about car customization being basic, but in this game there is so many colors and lights that you really only get to fully appreciate your car paint job when not driving.   I'm a fan of arcade racing games and music games, audiosurf was the actual reason I made a steam account in the first place, and I now own sevral custom-music based games. With a game like this, I was only naturaly drawn to it once I saw it in the featured store page, and I haft to say, this game is worth it. Very worth it. It is fun, simple, and effective at staying just that. If you like music-based games, specialy ones that use your music, I would highly recommend this, even if you're not a driving-game fan. This game has its heart in the music, and that is something I can appreciate.

												What interested me most about this game was drifting in sync to my music, which sounded like a match made in Heaven. There is a zen-like quality to drifting and chaining back to back corners that would seem to pair itself incredibly well to music based or 'rhythm' gaming. It took only a few minutes to realize that I would not be enjoying this game much at all. Unfortunately the 'drifting' is horrendous. I wasn't expecting too much, something akin to what is in a basic cart racing game. What ruins it is the complete lack of counter-steering. For those not familiar with counter-steering, it is the practice of turning your wheels opposite to the direction you turned to initiate the drift in order to maintain the cars balance to remain drifting instead of simply spinning out. It is the single most crucial aspect of drifting and Riff Racer misses it entirely. So what does this mean in terms of gameplay? It means that being able to guide your car and maintain a drift while sideways is effectively removed. You initiate the drift with a button press and then rely on the angle of your entry point along with your speed to remain drifting while continuing to spam the drift button. If you try to counter steer and maintain your drift the car immediately gains traction and sends you out of the drift and into the wall. It's a mind-boggling design decision that ruined the experience for me almost before it began.

												I like the concept here, but I feel the implementation lacks a little too much for me to give a recommendation.What's good?The idea of racing against the music's cursor. The race track length is equivalent to the song length, and you need to maintain a certain velocity to stay on cue with the song's "now playing" position. It's simple and novel.The music, for the most part. is enjoyable and fits the game well.The ability to use your own music for tracks.Multiple cars to use (and unlock).When you get going really fast and lights on the track pulse to the music. That's when you really feel the flow and is the game's real sweet spot in my opinion.What's not so good?As far as I can tell, the game has just one track style (road texture, skyline, roadside decor, etc.) that it uses over and over again. Every song I picked, even ones auto-generated from my music looked nearly identical. It seems you get a palette swap at best, and even then, a vast majority of the palettes I saw varied from red to pink. To boot, it's very monochromatic (more on that later).The car designs overall are fairly simplistic. They do fit the theme, but it's not like more detail on the cars would clash with the game's visual design.The controls leave me hankering for more precision steering. Given that the game can be played with one hand, it'd be nice to have a button you could press to enter into a fine-precision-steering mode where you didn't steer so acutely. The nature of the race courses rarely call for that, and when they do, it's very tricky to not end up over-correcting.The game's procedural generation of courses is rather bland. As noted before, the style is already repetitively used. Beyond that, there's actually little to do within a course. You collect turbo boost points (which when you've collected enough, you can juice your turbo). You also collect coins to unlock cars in your garage. Outside of those you have blockades, speed boosts, and ramps. The course itself twists, turns, and has gaps for you to jump over. But it all seems like it's a bit sparsely laid out for the sake of avoiding bad combinations that could result from the procedural generation of race courses.I expected to have more of the gameplay and course design attached to some aspect of the music (like ramps right before bass drops or something akin), but there doesn't really seem to be anything like that except for the aforementioned aspect of having pulsing lights to the beat when you're going super fast. I know a feature like this wouldn't be easy, but it would really help create unique and memorable experiences on the race track.Another ramification of the lacking variations in track features and colors is that when you're going turbo speed, the game blurs the camera. Now the game often puts blockades and ramps side-by-side. So with blurred vision, high speeds, and coming about a ramp-blockade combo from blind turns/twists/hills, I found myself often hitting the blockade instead of the ramp in that situation. It's not an insurmountable challenge, but it's an example of where the game's lacking of design and variation creates difficulty where there should be none. Why aren't blockades just given a different color to clearly separate them from ramps?On a few occasions, I ran into poorly generated courses such as ramps right into curves. For a game that's hinging on its procedural generation to create replayability, it really could use a bit of tweaking/polish.I like the game, but there are a few obstacles in the way of me enjoying it for any considerable duration. It feels like it's within reach of being a great title for zoning out to with the right music selections. If racing and/or rhythm games are in your wheelhouse and you are curious what a combination of the two genres would be like, then this is worth a pickup. But in its current state, I wouldn't generally recommend this game to people.

												If you like music runner games, as well as racing games, well then hot damn do I have a game for you!The game seems to be a blend of the arcade-y, drifting-based handling of Ridge Racer, and the intense color pallette/vibing feel of Audiosurf, from what I can tell after about 2 hours of play.On the positive side of the game, it so far has accurately synced up with any song i've thrown at it's engine; the music-generated maps change color and theme depending on the genre of music/intensity of the current moment in the song, with the choices in theme being appropriate thus far; there are many options in the way of what your car looks like, with unlockable rides that you can further customize after purchasing, all using in-game coins earned through playing the game. Kinda sad that has to be a positive side of a game nowadays, huh? Anyways, the actual "racing" itself is done against the pace of the song by way of pace bars you need to try to keep up with to stay synced with the song; the drifting and speed of the game feel incredibly satisfying, with speed boosts placed at areas where the song picks up, or usually, when it goes into a chorus. Also there are spin jumps, which are pretty awesome...when you land them.Now for the negative sides, starting with what I last mentioned. Because the game has spin jumps, it has a sort of physics engine which the car operates on while midair, and while the game encourages you to do spin jumps to score more points, the car can very easily flip and leave you wiping out, resetting your position between the second and third bars. This could just be a case of "i'm bad at the game," but it's rather irritating to lose your 100% sync rate because of something you have little control over; following up on that note, the game has barriers on the track that slow your car, which nine times out of ten, are completely avoidable. But sometimes you get that one time of the ten, where you can't see the barrier coming up because the track is going through a loop, and the song is ridiculously fast, so you get little to no time to react and lose a ton of speed. Again, could just be me being bad, but also again, it's not satisfying to get jipped out of your score because of that; the big complaint i've seen the most, no WMA support. Kinda lame, but it doesn't bother me personally too much, as most of my library is in mp3 format anyways, but I imagine that's a very large glaring issue for many people. Also, channeling my inner TotalBiscuit, the graphics options menu is limited to resolution, and fullscreen on/off, so if you can't run the game as is, you're kind of SOL. Sorry, yo.Overall, i've enjoyed the time i've put into the game, and I would recommend it to people who are fans of games such as Audiosurf, and Ridge Racer.

												Riff Racer (Previously known as Drive Any Track) is a racing game where the tracks are generated using your very own .mp3 files on your computer. I must say that this is an amazing concept! The tracks goes at the sync of your songs really well. Its impressive! It works especially very well with video game music.The graphics aren't the best graphics of our era, but they fit very well with the game. The interface is very simple and easy to use, which is excellent. I dont have anything to say about the sound. I mean, it's YOUR music, right? I'm not here to judge your musical preferences.I do have some issues with the gameplay. Yes, the track generation fits very well with your songs. There are achievements and even unlockable cars. Though, my only problem with the entire game is the driving. It's really difficult. The cars are very difficult to control, and turning your car is slow! It can be very difficult to avoid obstacles with that kind of steering, because Riff Racer is also a fast-paced game! Even if you have a lot of experience with racing games, you'll have a hard time when it comes to driving. Though, its not impossible to drive the cars, they're completely drivable. But what I am trying to say is that the driving NEEDS to be made easier. But overall, if you love music, if you love driving games, this is a must-have. While the game does have its problems, Riff Racer remains an amazing and enjoyable experience. It'll make you want to listen to more music!

												This game has a lot of potential and it could've been really fun, but it just isn't.The controls are extremely difficult to get use to, it's almost impossible to drift for more than 1 second, the game doesn't really feel like it's effected by your music when your playing, and the game completely butchers any sound that has bass to it. For example, if you were to play a dubstep song (since they have a lot of bass) or perhaps a trap song, it will sound like a distorted mess. The game just can't handle any bass for some reason. A lot of the odd curves and twists will just send you into a wall or will end with a ramp without giving you enough reaction time ultimately leading to you flying off of the track and into the abyss. The vehicle customization is very frustrating. At first from the trailer, I thought you immediately started the game being able to using everything you want right off the bat. Nope. You have to buy all the cars AND each individual "paintjob" for it, since there is no real customization like I was expecting. Earning money is also annoying. Everytime you start a new song you haven't played before, it will award you with 100 credits(?). Typically you earn between 100-150 in one song. The problem is cars will cost somewhere between 1,000-10,000. The cars (at least in my opinion) don't have a very great default paintjob, so you will try to get another one. Instead of them being free, the paintjobs on the very starter car are between 1,000-7,500 (if my memory is correct). The biggest problem I have with this "buy to unlock" system is that it makes playing the game feel more like a greedy race where every time you miss money, you can't help but to think "♥♥♥♥!" while you slam into a wall 3 seconds later. Not to mention about half of the money pickups you get don't even register. It just feels like an eternity to finally get enough money to buy something. The whole "relax and play" concept is just out the window for this game, which was a thing that made games like Audiosurf fun and kept you playing and wanting to try different songs.I really want to like this game but there's just too many problems right now. I'm probably going to refund this game, but I won't mind buying this game again if these problems are fixed.

 Warning: This game contains flashing lights, Online DRM required for non-bundled songs and framerate cap at 60 FPS lock.Other than that it’s very hard for me to find flaws in Riff Racer, it’s a simple concept bundled with a simple game but it all works together rather well. In case it isn’t obvious this is a racing game that turns any track from your music library into a racing track and places you into a ranking board with other people that have played the same song to measure your driving skills.The way the game calculates this score is kind of ingenious, whenever you’re starting a race a set of 4 lines flash very fast, these lines are actually the multiplier for your score and the least amount of mistakes (i.e. crashing against barriers, failing jumps and not drifting properly) that you get on a track, the most likely you’re going to be 100% “in sync” with the track and get a bigger bonus for doing so at the end. The racing itself feels pretty similar to Hotwheels: Turbo Racing, with the added feature of drifting and with free style tricks on jumps being removed and replaced with tricks based on your ability to line your car properly with ramps. Each car has its own set of stats, however these stats are not defined in the car selection screen and must be learned through playing with each and every single one of them, for instance some cars have better recovery time, some better handling and some have a boost that lasts longer, however these stats are absent when picking a car in the car selection screen.The game offer replay value in the form of unlockables, each car is actually sort of expensive and each car has its own set of skins that go with it that can go up to 25,000 in-game currency with each track giving you as between 200-500 in-game currency if you’re good. The game has absolutely no micro-transactions attached to it so unlocking everything can and will take a while.The one other problem that I do find with this game however is the fact that it can be pretty trial and error at times, due to the random nature of obstacles and jumps you will find yourself doing the same song over and over again until you get it right. But overall I think it’s worth the experience, to me it’s one of the best game to have come out of early access and one of the best games of the year in general, however it does require some amount of patience as the driving can take a while to get used to.

								Are you tired of buttonmashing in superfast songs in Audiosurf, but still want to race your own music?Well, this is a very nice alternative and its definitely worth 15 bucks.The gameplay is pretty simple: Drive with your car on a track generated by your song and try to keep up with the speed, while dodging obstacles, jumping and drifting. You can get a turbo for collecting little boxes spreaded all over the track. The faster you are, the more points you get. The End.The looks are.... decent. Definitely not Frostbite 3, but it´s on Audiosurf 2 level. It uses the "NEON EVERYWHERE."-Style, similar to Distance, but a bit brighter and with more colours. Also, nice by the way, all the lights on the track blink to the beat of the music.The tracks themselves don´t look awesome, they drive awesome. You have bumps, ramps, corkscrews, cliffs, giant bumps, loopings and many many corners to drive, boost, drift, dodge and jump through as the width of the track differs from corner to corner. But as I said, they don´t look awesome. Sure there´s NEON EVERYWHERE, but all you can see from the track are glowing columns hanging beside the track, neon fans and a city far, far away from the track. It looks quite empty.Overall this is already a very solid and fun game, although with ver 0.5.2 it seems to still have quite a way until full release. Looking for an Audiosurf alternative? Get this. Really, please.Features I would like to see in this game:-Workshop support for e.g. user created cars, environment styles, track hazards/gimmicks (them corkscrews and etc.)-An additional faster Gamemode, the standard is a bit slow IMO-Tachometer in BPM-Cockpit view, maybe?-Marathon mode (game/player chooses a few tracks of his library and the player has to drive them all   on one giant track)-AudioSync (tracks on the charts can be downloaded to drive)-Live Multiplayer (like the ghost feature, the cars all drive simultaneously on the track)
